Schedule III of the Companies Act, 2013 provides the manner in which the company registered under the Act should prepare its ‘Balance Sheet’, ‘Statement of Profit and Loss’ and ‘notes’.

 

Schedule III is divided into the following three divisions –

Division I - Financial Statements for a company whose Financial Statements are required to comply with the Companies (Accounting Standards) Rules, 2006

 

It covers the following –

1. General Instructions for preparation of Balance Sheet and Statement of Profit & Loss of a company;

2. Part I – Balance Sheet (format) along with general instructions for preparation of Balance Sheet:

3. Part II – Statement of Profit & Loss along with general instructions for preparation of Statement of Profit & Loss.

 

Division II - Financial Statements for a company whose Financial Statements are drawn up in compliance with the Companies (Indian Accounting Standards) Rules, 2015

 

It consists of the following –

1. General Instructions for preparation of the Financial Statement of a company that is required to comply with Ind AS;

2. Part I – Balance Sheet (format) along with general instructions for preparation of Balance Sheet:

3. Part II – Statement of Profit & Loss along with general instructions for preparing of the Statement of Profit & Loss.

4. Part III – General Instructions for preparation of the Consolidated Financial Statements

 

Division III - Financial Statements for NBFC (Non-Banking Financial Company) whose Financial Statements are drawn up in compliance with the Companies (Indian Accounting Standards) Rules, 2015

 

It consists of the following –

1. General Instructions for preparation of the Financial Statement of a non-banking financial company that is required to comply with Indian Accounting Standards;

2. Part I – Balance Sheet (format) along with general instructions for preparation of Balance Sheet:

3. Part II – Statement of Profit & Loss along with general instructions for preparing of the Statement of Profit & Loss.

4. Part III – General Instructions for preparation of the Consolidated Financial Statements.

Question 18
Which of the following does not form the part of the important information to be incorporated in the Memorandum of Association as specified in the Companies Act, 2013? (UGC NET Commerce Jul 2018)
  • A.The name of the company and the state in which it is situated.
  • B.The objects for which the company is proposed to be incorporated.
  • C.The rules, regulations and bye-laws for the internal management of the company.
  • D.The liability of the members of the company, whether limited or unlimited.
Correct Answer: The rules, regulations and bye-laws for the internal management of the company.

The rules, regulations and bye-laws for the internal management of the company are contained in Article of Association of the Company.

Question 19
To become a director in a company the person must obtain (UGC NET Commerce Jul 2016)
  • A.Business Licence
  • B.Director’s Licence
  • C.TIN
  • D.DIN
Correct Answer: DIN

To become a director in a company the person must obtain, Director Identification Number (DIN).

DIN is a unique Identification Number allotted to an individual who is appointed as a director of a company, upon making an application in form DIR-3 pursuant to section 153 & 154 of the Companies Act, 2013.

Question 20
When a person transacts with a company on matters which is beyond the power of the company, the person will be governed by the Doctrine of (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2014)
  • A.Management by Exception
  • B.Constructive Notice
  • C.Indoor Management
  • D.Self-Management
Correct Answer: Constructive Notice

Constructive Notice is a legal concept that relates to the knowledge or notice that a person is deemed to have regarding certain facts or information. It assumes that information that is publicly available or contained in official records is accessible to everyone and therefore should be known to them.

In the context of the given question, if a person transacts with a company on matters beyond the company's power, they would be governed by the Doctrine of Constructive Notice. This means that the person is expected to have knowledge of the company's limitations and powers as stated in its publicly available documents, such as its memorandum of association, articles of association, or other official records.

Question 21
The appropriate sequence of the formation of a company are in the following order: (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2014)
  • A.Promotion, commencement of business and incorporation
  • B.Promotion, incorporation, capital subscription and commencement of business
  • C.Capital subscription, promotion, incorporation and commencement of business
  • D.Incorporation, capital subscription, commencement of business and promotion
Correct Answer: Promotion, incorporation, capital subscription and commencement of business

The appropriate sequence of the formation of a company are in the following order:

 

Promotion: The first step in the formation of a company is promotion. It involves the identification of a business opportunity, bringing together the initial group of people who will invest in the company, and planning the structure and operations of the company.

 

Incorporation: After the promotion stage, the company is incorporated by completing the necessary legal formalities. This includes drafting the company's memorandum of association and articles of association and submitting them to the relevant government authorities to obtain the certificate of incorporation.

 

Capital Subscription: Once the company is incorporated, it can proceed with raising capital by inviting individuals or institutions to subscribe to its shares or debentures. This is typically done through a public issue or private placement.

 

Commencement of Business: After the company has raised the required capital, it can commence its business operations. This involves putting the company's plans into action, hiring employees, acquiring assets, and starting its revenue-generating activities.

Question 22
The Companies Act, 2013 came into force in ____________.
  • A.April 2013
  • B.June 2013
  • C.August 2013
  • D.September 2013
Correct Answer: August 2013

The Companies Act, 2013 received the assent of hon’ble President of India on 29th August 2013.

Question 23
The Companies Act, 2013 has total _____ schedules.
  • A.7
  • B.8
  • C.9
  • D.10
Correct Answer: 7

The Companies Act, 2013 has 470 sections and 7 schedules. It is divided into 29 chapters. This Act aims to improve corporate governance, simplify regulations and strengthen the interests of investors.

Question 24
How many minimum numbers of members required to form Private Limited Company?
  • A.2
  • B.3
  • C.5
  • D.7
Correct Answer: 2

The minimum number of members required to form Private Limited Company is 2.

Question 25
How many minimum numbers of members required to form Public Limited Company?
  • A.2
  • B.3
  • C.5
  • D.7
Correct Answer: 7

The minimum number of members required to form Public Limited Company is 7.

Question 26
Nominal Capital with respect to a Company means?
  • A.Authorized capital
  • B.Issued Capital
  • C.Paid Up Capital
  • D.Called Up Capital
Correct Answer: Authorized capital

Authorised capital (nominal capital) means such capital as is authorised by the memorandum of a company to be the maximum amount of share capital of the company.

 

Called-up capital means such part of the capital, which has been called for payment.

 

Issued capital means such capital as the company issues from time to time for subscription.

 

Paid-up share capital means aggregate of the amount of money credited as paid-up as is equivalent to the amount received as paid-up in respect of issued shares and also includes any amount credited as paid-up in respect of shares of the company.

Question 27
Which of the following is issued to a Company on its Incorporation?
  • A.DIN
  • B.CIN
  • C.PIN
  • D.GIN
Correct Answer: CIN

On and from the date of incorporation, the Registrar shall allot to the Company a Corporate Identification Number (CIN), which shall be a distinct identity for the company and which shall also be included in the certificate.

Question 28
Which of the following is not the characteristic feature of a One Person Company (OPC)?
  • A.Simplified procedural requirements
  • B.Separate Legal Entity
  • C.Unlimited Liability
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: Unlimited Liability

A new concept has been introduced in the Company’s Act 2013, about the One Person Company (OPC). In a Private Company, a minimum of 2 Directors and Members are required whereas in a Public Company, a minimum of 3 Directors and a minimum of 7 members. A single person could not incorporate a Company previously. But now as per Section 2(62) of the Company’s Act 2013, a company can be formed with just 1 Director and 1 member. It is a form of a company where the compliance requirements are lesser than that of a private company.

 

The Act classifies OPC as a private company for all the legal purposes with only one member. All the provisions related to the private company are applicable to an OPC, unless otherwise expressly excluded. Hence, the company will have limited liability.

Question 29
Under the Companies Act, 2013, which of the following companies are popularly known as Section 8 Companies?
  • A.One Person Companies
  • B.Non-profit Companies
  • C.Listed Companies
  • D.Dormant Companies
Correct Answer: Non-profit Companies

Companies for charitable purpose are popularly known as Sec. 8 Companies. These limited company (a) has in its objects the promotion of commerce, art, science, sports, education, research, social welfare, religion, charity, protection of environment or any such other object; (b) intends to apply its profits, if any, or other income in promoting its objects; and (c) intends to prohibit the payment of any dividend to its members.

Examples of section 8 companies are FICCI, ASSOCHAM, National Sports Club of India, CII etc. The Central Government may, by licence issued allow that person or association of persons to be registered as a limited company under this section without the addition to its name of the word "Limited", or as the case may be, the words "Private Limited".

Question 30
Match the following:List 1 (Types of Companies)(a) Dormant(b)Nidhi(c) SmallList 2 (Definition/ feature)(i) Other than a public Company(ii) to cultivate habit of thrift and saving(iii) No significant Accounting TransactionCodes:
  • A.(a)-(iii), (b)-(ii), (c)-(i)
  • B.(a)-(i), (b)-(ii), (c)-(iii)
  • C.(a)-(ii), (b)-(i), (c)-(iii)
  • D.(a)-(ii), (b)-(iii), (c)-(i)
Correct Answer: (a)-(iii), (b)-(ii), (c)-(i)

List I – List II

(a) Dormant - No significant Accounting Transaction

(b) Nidhi - to cultivate habit of thrift and saving

(c) Small - Other than a public Company

 

As per Companies Act, 2013, Company means a company incorporated under this Act or under any previous company law.

 

Following are the types of Companies under the Act.

 

Company limited by guarantee means a company having limited liability of its members limited to the extent undertaken by them to contribute to the assets of the company in the event of its being wound up.

 

Company limited by shares means a company having limited liability of its members limited to the amount, if any, unpaid on the shares held by them.

 

Unlimited company means a company not having any limit on the liability of its members.

 

Associate company, in relation to another company, means a company in which that other company has a significant influence, but which is not a subsidiary company of the company having such influence and includes a joint venture company

“Significant influence” means control of at least 20% of total share capital, or of business decisions under an agreement; and the expression "Joint venture" means a joint arrangement whereby the parties that have joint control of the arrangement have rights to the net assets of the arrangement

The term “Total Share Capital”, means the aggregate of the -

(a) Paid-up equity share capital; and

(b) Convertible preference share capital.

 

One Person Company (OPC) means a company which has only one person as a member

 

Private Company means a company having a prescribed minimum paid-up share capital and which (i) restricts the right to transfer its shares (ii) except in case of One Person Company, limits the number of its members to 200 (iii) prohibits any invitation to the public to subscribe for any securities of the company.

The Act says that private companies can have a maximum of 200 members (except for One Person Companies). This number does not include present and former employees who are also members. Moreover, more than 2 persons who own shares jointly are treated as a single member.

 

Public Company means a company which (a) is not a private company; (b) has a prescribed minimum paid-up share capital.

Please note that a private company which is a subsidiary of public company, shall be deemed to be public company for the purposes of this Act even where such subsidiary company continues to be a private company in its articles.

 

Government company means any company in which not less than 51% of the paid-up share capital is held by (a) the Central Government, or (b) by any State Government or Governments, or (c) partly by the Central Government and partly by one or more State Governments, and (d) includes a company which is a subsidiary company of such a Government company.

 

Small company means a company, other than a public company (i) paid-up share capital of which does not exceed Rs. 50 Lakhs or such prescribed higher amount up to a maximum of Rs. 10 crore; and (ii) turnover of which does not exceed Rs. 2 crore or such prescribed higher amount up to a maximum of Rs. 100 crore.

Nothing in this clause shall apply to—

(a) a holding company or a subsidiary company;

(b) a company registered under section 8 (Non profit Companies); or

(c) a company or body corporate governed by any special Act.

 

Holding company, in relation to one or more other companies, means a company of which such companies are subsidiary companies.

 

Subsidiary company, in relation to any other company (that is to say the holding company), means a company in which the holding company (i) controls the composition of the BOD; or (ii) exercises or controls more than ½ of the total voting power either at its own or together with one or more of its subsidiary companies.

 

Listed company means a company which has any of its securities listed on any recognised stock exchange.

 

Dormant company means a company formed and registered for a future project or to hold an asset or intellectual property and has no significant accounting transaction (during the last two financial years).

 

Foreign company means any company or body corporate incorporated outside India which (a) has a place of business in India whether by itself or through an agent, physically or through electronic mode; and (b) conducts any business activity in India in any other manner.

 

Banking company means a banking company as defined in clause (c) of section 5 of the Banking Regulation Act, 1949.

 

Nidhi company means a company which has been incorporated as a Nidhi with the object of cultivating the habit of thrift and savings amongst its members, receiving deposits from, and lending to, its members only, for their mutual benefit.

 

Companies for charitable purpose (popularly known as Sec. 8 Companies) A limited company (a) has in its objects the promotion of commerce, art, science, sports, education, research, social welfare, religion, charity, protection of environment or any such other object; (b) intends to apply its profits, if any, or other income in promoting its objects; and (c) intends to prohibit the payment of any dividend to its members. Examples of section 8 companies are FICCI, ASSOCHAM, National Sports Club of India, CII etc.

Question 31
Promoter with respect to a Company means
  • A.who has been named as such in a prospectus or annual return of the company;
  • B.who has control over the affairs of the company;
  • C.in accordance with whose advice or directions, the BOD is accustomed to act except person acting in a professional capacity
  • D.All of the above
Correct Answer: All of the above

Promoter means a person:

(a) who has been named as such in a prospectus or annual return of the company;

(b) who has control over the affairs of the company;

(c) in accordance with whose advice or directions, the BOD is accustomed to act except person acting in a professional capacity.

Question 32
For a Company to be called ‘Associate Company’ under Companies Act 2013, the ‘significant influence’ means control of?
  • A.at least 10% of total share capital
  • B.at least 20% of total share capital
  • C.at least 25% of total share capital
  • D.at least 5% of total share capital
Correct Answer: at least 20% of total share capital

Associate company, in relation to another company, means a company in which that other company has a significant influence, but which is not a subsidiary company of the company having such influence and includes a joint venture company.

“Significant influence” means control of at least 20% of total share capital, or of business decisions under an agreement; and the expression "Joint venture" means a joint arrangement whereby the parties that have joint control of the arrangement have rights to the net assets of the arrangement

 

The term “Total Share Capital”, means the aggregate of the -

(a) Paid-up equity share capital; and

(b) Convertible preference share capital.

Question 33
The article of association needs to be signed by?
  • A.All proposed directors
  • B.Registrar
  • C.Subscribers of memorandum
  • D.None of above
Correct Answer: Subscribers of memorandum

The article of association needs to be signed by Subscribers of memorandum.

Question 34
Which of the following company cannot give invitation to public for any shares in the company?
  • A.Statutory Company
  • B.Private Company
  • C.Registered Company
  • D.Subsidiary Company
Correct Answer: Private Company

A private company cannot give invitation to public for any shares in the Company.

Question 35
Producer company is based on the principles of?
  • A.Patronage
  • B.Mutual Assistance
  • C.Limited Return
  • D.All of the above
Correct Answer: All of the above

A producer company is a company incorporated under Companies Act 2013 (formerly the Companies Act 1956) and shall carry on following activities as mentioned in section 581B of Companies Act 1956:

• Production, harvesting, procurement, grading, pooling, handling, marketing, selling, export of primary produce of the Members or import goods for their benefit

• Processing including preserving, drying, distilling, brewing, venting, canning and packaging of produce of its members

• Manufacture, sale or supply of machinery, equipment or consumables mainly to its Members

• Providing education on the mutual assistance principles to its Members and others

• Rendering technical services, consultancy services, training, research and development and all other activities for the promotion of interest of its members

• Generation, transmission and distribution of power, revitalisation of land and water resources, their use, conservation and communications relatable to primary produce

• Insurance of producers or their primary produce

• Promoting techniques of mutuality and mutual assistance

• Welfare measures or facilities for the benefit of Members as may be decided by the Board

• Any other activity, ancillary or incidental to any of the activities referred to in above clauses which may promote the principles of mutuality and mutual assistance amongst the Members in any other manner

• Financing of procurement, processing, marketing or other activities specified in above clauses which include extending credit facilities or any other financial services to its members.

Question 36
In the guarantee Company having share capital, the liability of shareholders will be?
  • A.Guarantee + unpaid value of shares
  • B.Unpaid value of shares
  • C.Unlimited
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: Guarantee + unpaid value of shares

In the guarantee Company having share capital, the liability of shareholders will be limited to guarantee plus unpaid value of shares.

Question 37
In the guarantee Company having no share capital, the liability of shareholders will be?
  • A.To the extent of guarantee
  • B.Unpaid value of shares
  • C.Unlimited
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: To the extent of guarantee

In the guarantee Company having no share capital, the liability of shareholders will be limited to the extent of guarantee.

Question 38
Which company shares can be freely transferable?
  • A.Private Company
  • B.Public Company
  • C.Both A & B
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: Public Company

Shares of the Public Company are freely transferable.

 

As per Companies Act, 2013, a Private Company means a company having a prescribed minimum paid-up share capital and which:

(i) restricts the right to transfer its shares;

(ii) except in case of One Person Company, limits the number of its members to 200;

(iii) prohibits any invitation to the public to subscribe for any securities of the company.

 

The Act says that private companies can have a maximum of 200 members (except for One Person Companies). This number does not include present and former employees who are also members. Moreover, more than two persons who own shares jointly are treated as a single member.

 

Public Company means a company which:

(a) is not a private company;

(b) has a prescribed minimum paid-up share capital.

A private company which is a subsidiary of public company, shall be deemed to be public company for the purposes of this Act even where such subsidiary company continues to be a private company in its articles

Question 39
How many members should sign the MOA in case of public company?
  • A.1
  • B.3
  • C.5
  • D.7
Correct Answer: 7

In case of a public company, minimum seven (7) members who need to sign Memorandum of Association.

 

Section 3(1) of the Companies Act, 2013 states that a company may be formed for any lawful purpose by—

(a) 7 or more persons, in case of a public company;

(b) 2 or more persons, in case of a private company; or

(c) one person, in case of a One Person Company that is to say, a private company

by subscribing their names or his name to a memorandum and complying with the requirements of this Act in respect of registration.

Question 40
Property of the company belongs to?
  • A.Shareholders
  • B.Company
  • C.Members
  • D.Promoters
Correct Answer: Company

Property of the Company belongs to Company.

A Company is a legal person and is different from its members. The property of the Company belongs to the Company alone and the members cannot claim individually or jointly ownership rights in the assets of the company during its existence or in its winding up.

Question 41
Which one of the following is not the content of the Memorandum of Association?
  • A.Name Clause
  • B.Domicile Clause
  • C.Object Clause
  • D.Board of Directors Clause
Correct Answer: Board of Directors Clause

Board of Directors Clause is not the content of the Memorandum of Association (MOA). The provisions of the Companies Act, 2013 with respect to MOA are as follows:

 

Memorandum of Association (MOA) of the Company (Sec. 4)

The Act states that the memorandum of a company shall state:

(a) the name of the company with the last word "Limited" [in the case of a public limited company, or the last words "Private Limited" in the case of a private limited company], except Sec. 8 Companies

(b) The State in which the registered office of the company is to be situated

(c) The objects for which the company is proposed to be incorporated

(d) the liability of members of the company

(e) in the case of a company having a share capital:

(i) the amount of share capital with which the company is to be registered and

(ii) the number of shares each subscriber to the memorandum intends to take

(f) in the case of OPC, the name of the person who in the event of death of the subscriber shall become the member of the company.

Question 42
An Act is said to be ultra vires a company when it is beyond the powers
  • A.of the Company
  • B.of the Directors
  • C.of the Directors but not the Company
  • D.conferred on the Company by the Articles of Association
Correct Answer: of the Company

An Act is said to be ultra vires a company when it is beyond the powers of the Company.

 

The Doctrine of Ultra Vires is explained below.

 

The word ‘ultra’ means beyond and the word ‘vires’ means powers.

 

In the case of a company whatever is not stated in the memorandum as the objects or powers is prohibited by the doctrine of ultra vires. As a result, an act which is ultra vires is void, and does not bind the company. Neither the company nor the contracting party can sue on it. Also, as stated earlier, the company cannot make it valid, even if every member assent to it.

 

The general rule is that an act which is ultra vires the company is incapable of ratification. An act which is intra vires the company but outside the authority of the directors may be ratified by the company in proper form.

 

The rule is meant to protect shareholders and the creditors of the company. If the act is ultra vires (beyond the powers of) the directors only, the shareholders can ratify it. If it is ultra vires the articles of association, the company can alter its articles in the proper way and thereby such acts can be duly ratified.

 

The ultra vires acts are null and void ab initio.

Question 43
A Private Company which is a subsidiary of a Public Company is treated as?
  • A.Public Company
  • B.Private Company
  • C.Holding Company
  • D.Family Company
Correct Answer: Public Company

A Private Company which is a subsidiary of a Public Company is treated as Public Company.

 

Under the Companies Act, 2013, Public Company means a company which:

(a) is not a private company;

(b) has a prescribed minimum paid-up share capital.

A private company which is a subsidiary of public company, shall be deemed to be public company for the purposes of this Act even where such subsidiary company continues to be a private company in its articles.

Question 44
Who among the following are identified as the Key managerial personnel in the Indian Companies Act 2013? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2022)(a) Chief Executive Officer.(b) Whole Time Director.(c) Company Secretary.(d) Chief Risk Officer.(e) ManagerChoose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.a, b and d only.
  • B.aand b only.
  • C.a, b, c and d only.
  • D.a, b, c and e only.
Correct Answer: a, b, c and e only.

As per the provisions of the Companies Act, 2013, Key managerial personnel (KMP) in relation to a Company, means: (i) the CEO or MD or Manager; (ii) the company secretary; (iii) the whole-time director; (iv) the Chief Financial Officer; (v) such other officer, not more than one level below the directors (designated as KMP by the Board); (vi) such other prescribed officer.

Question 45
As per Section 68 of the Indian Companies Act, a company may purchase its own shares out of which of the following? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2022)(a) Free reserves(b) Securities premium account(c) General reserve(d) Proceeds of any other shares(e) Proceeds of same kind of sharesChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.a, b, c and e only.
  • B.a, b, c and d only.
  • C.b, c, d and e only.
  • D.a, c, d and e only.
Correct Answer: a, b, c and d only.

Section 68 of the Companies Act, 2013 empowers a company to purchase its own shares or other securities in certain cases. A company may purchase its shares out of:

♦ Its free reserves;

♦ The securities premium account; or

♦ The proceeds of the issue of any shares or other specified securities.

However, no buy-back of any kind of shares can be made out of the proceeds of an earlier issue of the same kind of shares.

Question 46
Read the following paragraph and answer the five questions that follow(Questions 3 to 7):(UGC NET Commerce Jun 2022)Section 455 of Indian Companies Act, 2013 talks about a New Provision Calls "DORMANT COMPANY'. This concept was not there in Companies Act, 1956.A Dormant Company offers excellent advantage to the promoters who want to hold an asset or intellectual property under the corporate shield for its usage at a later stage. For instance: if a promoter wants to buy lands now for its future project at a comparatively lesser price, he may do the same through dormant company so that he can use the land for its future project. Thus, dormant company status is a new phenomenon in the Companies Act 2013 and is an excellent tool for keeping assets in the company for its future usage. A dormant company may be either a public company or a private company or a one-person company.Certain companies, due to the nature of their business, may not be able to start any business, for a long time from the date of incorporation as for instance any business for creation of intellectual property or for a future project and has no significant accounting transaction. Such a company may be an Inactive company". Construction Companies/Real Estate Companies incorporate New Companies to hold land/properties for future projects. This concept is beneficial for them. By this concept, they can Incorporate Company and purchase property/land in that company and get status of Dormant Company. If a company gets status of dormant company, there are less compliance in dormant company in comparison of active company. It will help to save cost of compliances for inactive companies.Which one of the following nature of business is suitable to a Dormant company? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2022)
  • A.Shipping business
  • B.Manufacturing business
  • C.Real Estate business
  • D.Pharmaceutical business
Correct Answer: Real Estate business

The given passage states that Construction Companies/Real Estate Companies incorporate New Companies to hold land/properties for future projects.

Question 47
Read the following paragraph and answer the five questions that follow(Questions 3 to 7):(UGC NET Commerce Jun 2022)Section 455 of Indian Companies Act, 2013 talks about a New Provision Calls "DORMANT COMPANY'. This concept was not there in Companies Act, 1956.A Dormant Company offers excellent advantage to the promoters who want to hold an asset or intellectual property under the corporate shield for its usage at a later stage. For instance: if a promoter wants to buy lands now for its future project at a comparatively lesser price, he may do the same through dormant company so that he can use the land for its future project. Thus, dormant company status is a new phenomenon in the Companies Act 2013 and is an excellent tool for keeping assets in the company for its future usage. A dormant company may be either a public company or a private company or a one-person company.Certain companies, due to the nature of their business, may not be able to start any business, for a long time from the date of incorporation as for instance any business for creation of intellectual property or for a future project and has no significant accounting transaction. Such a company may be an Inactive company". Construction Companies/Real Estate Companies incorporate New Companies to hold land/properties for future projects. This concept is beneficial for them. By this concept, they can Incorporate Company and purchase property/land in that company and get status of Dormant Company. If a company gets status of dormant company, there are less compliance in dormant company in comparison of active company. It will help to save cost of compliances for inactive companies.Which of the following companies may fall under a purview of Dormant company? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2022)a. Private companyb. One person companyc. Public companyChoose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.a and b
  • B.b and c
  • C.c and a
  • D.a, b and c

Question 48
Read the following paragraph and answer the five questions that follow(Questions 3 to 7):(UGC NET Commerce Jun 2022)Section 455 of Indian Companies Act, 2013 talks about a New Provision Calls "DORMANT COMPANY'. This concept was not there in Companies Act, 1956.A Dormant Company offers excellent advantage to the promoters who want to hold an asset or intellectual property under the corporate shield for its usage at a later stage. For instance: if a promoter wants to buy lands now for its future project at a comparatively lesser price, he may do the same through dormant company so that he can use the land for its future project. Thus, dormant company status is a new phenomenon in the Companies Act 2013 and is an excellent tool for keeping assets in the company for its future usage. A dormant company may be either a public company or a private company or a one person company.Certain companies, due to the nature of their business, may not be able to start any business, for a long time from the date of incorporation as for instance any business for creation of intellectual property or for a future project and has no significant accounting transaction. Such a company may be an Inactive company". Construction Companies/Real Estate Companies incorporate New Companies to hold land/properties for future projects. This concept is beneficial for them. By this concept, they can Incorporate Company and purchase property/land in that company and get status of Dormant Company. If a company gets status of dormant company, there are less compliance in dormant company in comparison of active company. It will help to save cost of compliances for inactive companies.Given below are two statements: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2022)One is labelled as Assertion A and the other is labelled as Reason R.Assertion A: Provision is made to obtain the status of a 'dormant company' forainactive company that doesn't trade.Reasons R: Dormant company doesn't trade but has significant accounting transaction.In the light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.Both A and R are correct R is the correct explanation of A.
  • B.Both A and R are correct but R is NOT the correct explanation of A.
  • C.A is correct but R is not correct.
  • D.A is not correct but R is correct
Correct Answer: A is correct but R is not correct.

The passage states that certain companies, due to the nature of their business, may not be able to start any business, for a long time from the date of incorporation as for instance any business for creation of intellectual property or for a future project and has no significant accounting transaction. Such a company may be an Inactive company". Such a company may be an Inactive company". Construction Companies/Real Estate Companies/Incorporate New Companies to hold land/properties for future projects. This concept is beneficial for them. By this concept, they can Incorporate Company and purchase property/land in that company and get status of Dormant Company.

 

Therefore, A is correct but R is not correct.

Question 49
Read the following paragraph and answer the five questions that follow(Questions 3 to 7):(UGC NET Commerce Jun 2022)Section 455 of Indian Companies Act, 2013 talks about a New Provision Calls "DORMANT COMPANY'. This concept was not there in Companies Act, 1956.A Dormant Company offers excellent advantage to the promoters who want to hold an asset or intellectual property under the corporate shield for its usage at a later stage. For instance: if a promoter wants to buy lands now for its future project at a comparatively lesser price, he may do the same through dormant company so that he can use the land for its future project. Thus, dormant company status is a new phenomenon in the Companies Act 2013 and is an excellent tool for keeping assets in the company for its future usage. A dormant company may be either a public company or a private company or a one person company.Certain companies, due to the nature of their business, may not be able to start any business, for a long time from the date of incorporation as for instance any business for creation of intellectual property or for a future project and has no significant accounting transaction. Such a company may be an Inactive company". Construction Companies/Real Estate Companies incorporate New Companies to hold land/properties for future projects. This concept is beneficial for them. By this concept, they can Incorporate Company and purchase property/land in that company and get status of Dormant Company. If a company gets status of dormant company, there are less compliance in dormant company in comparison of active company. It will help to save cost of compliances for inactive companies.Dormant company offers excellent advantage to which one of the following? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2022)
  • A.Bankers
  • B.Creditors
  • C.Shareholders
  • D.Promoters
Correct Answer: Promoters

The passage states that a Dormant Company offers excellent advantage to the promoters who want to hold an asset or intellectual property under the corporate shield for its usage at a later stage.

Question 50
Read the following paragraph and answer the five questions that follow(Questions 3 to 7):(UGC NET Commerce Jun 2022)Section 455 of Indian Companies Act, 2013 talks about a New Provision Calls "DORMANT COMPANY'. This concept was not there in Companies Act, 1956.A Dormant Company offers excellent advantage to the promoters who want to hold an asset or intellectual property under the corporate shield for its usage at a later stage. For instance: if a promoter wants to buy lands now for its future project at a comparatively lesser price, he may do the same through dormant company so that he can use the land for its future project. Thus, dormant company status is a new phenomenon in the Companies Act 2013 and is an excellent tool for keeping assets in the company for its future usage. A dormant company may be either a public company or a private company or a one person company.Certain companies, due to the nature of their business, may not be able to start any business, for a long time from the date of incorporation as for instance any business for creation of intellectual property or for a future project and has no significant accounting transaction. Such a company may be an Inactive company". Construction Companies/Real Estate Companies incorporate New Companies to hold land/properties for future projects. This concept is beneficial for them. By this concept, they can Incorporate Company and purchase property/land in that company and get status of Dormant Company. If a company gets status of dormant company, there are less compliance in dormant company in comparison of active company. It will help to save cost of compliances for inactive companies.Given below are two statements: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2022)One is labelled as Assertion A and the other is labelled as Reason R.Assertion A: If a company gets status of a dormant company, then it is subject to less compliance in comparison to active company.Reasons R: It will help to save of compliances for Inactive companies when they become dormant company under section 455 of the Companies Act, 2013 as compared to the Companies Act, 1956.In the light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.Both A and R are correct and R is the correct explanation of A.
  • B.Both A and R are correct but (R) is NOT the correct explanation of A.
  • C.A is correct but R is not correct.
  • D.A is not correct but R is correct.
Correct Answer: Both A and R are correct and R is the correct explanation of A.

Both A and R are correct and R is the correct explanation of A.

Quiz Attempt #119479

Total Questions: 40
Question 1
Consider the following statements and choose the correct option that follows:Statement I: An IPO is used by an already listed company to raise more money.Statement II: An FPO refers to fresh (first time) issue of shares to public.Codes:
  • A.Both statements are correct.
  • B.Statement I is correct and Statement II is incorrect.
  • C.Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is correct.
  • D.Both statements are incorrect.
Correct Answer: Both statements are incorrect.

Both Statements are incorrect.

 

An Initial Public Offer (IPO): It is when a company which is presently not listed at any stock exchange makes either a fresh issue of shares or makes an offer for sale of its existing shares or both for the first time to the public.

Further Public Issue (FPO): Shares that are issued by a company that has already been listed on the stock exchange and want to raise more money from the market by issuing subsequent shares of that company.

Question 2
How many members should sign the MOA in case of private company?
  • A.1
  • B.2
  • C.3
  • D.4
Correct Answer: 2

In case of a private company, minimum two (2) members who need to sign Memorandum of Association.

 

Section 3(1) of the Companies Act, 2013 states that a company may be formed for any lawful purpose by—

(a) 7 or more persons, in case of a public company;

(b) 2 or more persons, in case of a private company; or

(c) one person, in case of a One Person Company that is to say, a private company

by subscribing their names or his name to a memorandum and complying with the requirements of this Act in respect of registration.

Question 3
DIN is allotted with reference to:
  • A.Domestic Company
  • B.Director
  • C.Designated Officer
  • D.None of the Above
Correct Answer: Director

Every person who is to be appointed as a director must have “Director’s Identification Number (DIN), therefore, DIN is allotted to a Director.

Question 4
Which of the following documents contain the rules and regulations to govern the internal management of the company?
  • A.Company Act 2013
  • B.Memorandum of Association
  • C.Prospectus
  • D.Articles of Association
Correct Answer: Articles of Association

Articles of Association of the Company contains the rules and regulation to govern the internal management of the Company. It is explained below:

 

The articles of association is comprised of following provisions:

(a) Share capital, call of share, forfeiture of share, conversion of share into stock, transfer of shares, share warrant, surrender of shares, etc.

(b) Directors, their qualifications, appointment, remuneration, powers, and proceedings of the board of directors’ meetings.

(c) Voting rights of shareholders, by poll or proxies and proceeding of shareholders general meetings.

(d) Dividends and reserves, accounts and audits, borrowing powers and winding up.

Question 5
A person who raises a concern about wrongdoing within an organization is called?
  • A.Promoter
  • B.Whistle Blower
  • C.Inside Trader
  • D.Auditor
Correct Answer: Whistle Blower

A person who raises a concern about wrongdoing within an organisation is called Whistle Blower. A whistle blower is a person who comes forward and shares his/her knowledge on any wrongdoing which he/she thinks is happening in the whole organisation or in a specific department. A whistle blower could be an employee, contractor, or a supplier who becomes aware of any illegal activities. To protect whistle blowers from losing their job or getting mistreated there are specific laws. Most companies have a separate policy which clearly states how to report such an incident. A whistle blower can file a lawsuit or register a complaint with higher authorities which will trigger a criminal investigation against the company or any individual department.

 

There are two types of whistle blowers: internal and external. Internal whistle blowers are those who report the misconduct, fraud, or indiscipline to senior officers of the organisation such as Head Human Resource or CEO. External whistleblowing is a term used when whistle blowers report the wrongdoings to people outside the organisation such as the media, higher government officials, or police.

 

The crime or wrongdoing could be in the form of fraud, deceiving employees, corruptions, or any other act which misleads people. The Whistle Blowers Protection Act, 2011 lays down the complete framework to investigate alleged cases of wrongdoing.

Question 6
Within how many days of its incorporation, a Company needs to inform Registrar of Companies (ROC) about its Registered office?
  • A.30
  • B.60
  • C.90
  • D.120
Correct Answer: 30

A company shall, (within 30 days of its incorporation) and at all times thereafter, have a registered office. The company shall furnish to the Registrar verification of its registered office within a period of 30 days of its incorporation.

Question 7
A company may raise money from capital market through issue of?
  • A.MOA
  • B.AOA
  • C.Prospectus
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: Prospectus

A company may raise money from capital market through issue of prospectus.

Question 8
Within how many days of receipt of share application money, the shares should be allotted to a shareholder from whom such share application money has been received?
  • A.30 days
  • B.45 days
  • C.60 days
  • D.90 days
Correct Answer: 60 days

The company shall allot its securities within 60 days from the date of receipt of application money, if it does not allot within 60 days then the application money shall be repaid within 15 days after the expiry of 60 days and if company does not pay money after the aforesaid period, the company is liable to repay the money with interest @ 12% per annum from the expiry of 60 days.

Question 9
For which of the following purposes, a securities premium account can be utilized?
  • A.issue of bonus shares
  • B.writing off preliminary expenses
  • C.buy back of its own securities
  • D.All of the above
Correct Answer: All of the above

The amount which is in excess of the issue price of a share over its face value (or par value) is referred to as ‘share premium. It is the difference between the price at which a company issues a share and the face value of a share. Section 52 of the Companies Act, 2013 deals with the application of premium received on issue of shares. Where a company issues shares at a premium, whether for cash or otherwise, a sum equal to the aggregate amount or value of the premium on those shares shall be transferred to an account, to be called, “securities premium account”. The securities premium account may be applied by the company—

(a) towards the issue of unissued shares of the company to the members of the company as fully paid bonus shares;

(b) in writing off the preliminary expenses of the company;

(c) in writing off the expenses of, or the commission paid or discount allowed on, any issue of shares or debentures of the company;

(d) in providing for the premium payable on the redemption of any redeemable preference shares or of any debentures of the company; or

(e) for the purchase of its own shares or other securities.

Question 10
The issue of shares at discount is void under Companies Act, 2013 except in case(s) of:
  • A.conversion of debt into shares pursuant to restructuring scheme
  • B.Issue of sweat equity shares
  • C.Both A and B
  • D.Neither A nor B
Correct Answer: Both A and B

The Companies Act, 2013 prohibits a company to issue shares at discount except in the case of issue of sweat equity shares. Any shares issued by a Company at a discount price shall be void. A company may also issue shares at a discount to its creditors when its debt is converted into shares in pursuance of any statutory resolution plan or debt restructuring scheme.

Question 11
The existing shareholders can exercise their ‘pre-emptive right’ during which of the following?
  • A.Issue of Bonus Shares
  • B.ESOPs
  • C.Right Issue
  • D.Preferential Allotment
Correct Answer: Right Issue

A rights issue is a way by which a company can raise additional capital. However, instead of going to the public, the company gives its existing shareholders the right to subscribe to newly issued shares in proportion to their existing holdings. For example, 1:4 rights issue means an existing shareholder can buy 1 extra share for every 4 shares already held by him. Usually the price at which the new shares are issued by way of rights issue is less than the prevailing market. This is also known as ‘pre-emptive’ right (in preference to outsiders) available to existing shareholders. In other words, whenever a Company is in requirement of capital, then it shall offer its shares to its existing shareholders first in proportion to the shares held by them already and if they refuse or renounce the offer, then only the Company can offer it to an outsider. The prescribed time limit for Right issue offer is a time not being less than 15 days and not exceeding 30 days from the date of the offer within which the offer, if not accepted, shall be deemed to have been declined.

Question 12
A company is not permissible to issue fully paid-up bonus shares to its members out of which of the following?
  • A.Free reserves
  • B.Revaluation Reserves
  • C.Securities Premium Account
  • D.Capital Redemption Reserve Account
Correct Answer: Revaluation Reserves

A company may issue fully paid-up bonus shares to its members, in any manner whatsoever, out of –

(i) Its free reserves;

(ii) The securities premium account; or

(iii) The capital redemption reserve account.

It is to be noted that no issue of bonus shares shall be made by capitalizing reserves created by the revaluation of assets, which means bonus shares cannot be issued out of revaluation reserves. The bonus shares shall not be issued in lieu of dividend. The company which has once announced the decision of its Board recommending a bonus issue, shall not subsequently withdraw the same.

Question 13
At present the number of depositories operating in India are?
  • A.One
  • B.Two
  • C.Three
  • D.Four
Correct Answer: Two

At present the number of depositories operating in India are 2 (Two).

 

Depositories are integral institutions in the Indian Capital Market and their functionality can be compared to banking entities.

 

Their role comes into play from the time an investor decides on investing. In India, there are two depositories namely National Securities Depository Limited (NSDL) or Central Depository Services (India) Limited (CDSL) that are registered with SEBI.

 

Both NSDL and CDSL, facilitate dematerialization of shares i.e. held the shares in electronic form. So, in a way depository is held accountable for safe-keeping of your portfolio of securities. On instruction of the account holder, depositories also facilitate transfer of securities from one account to the other. So, transfer of ownership of securities is affected by depositories. With all the details concerning your personal details, scrips as well the number of units of each scrip held by the individual, several corporate actions or transactions such as the issue of bonus shares or annual dividend are executed via depositories acting as an important intermediary in the entire process. So, the depository other than acting as a safe-keeper of your securities provides services pertaining to the transaction in securities.

 

The two depositories in India provide their services to large investor base through depository participants. As per SEBI rules, banks, financial institutions as well as trading members registered with SEBI are eligible to act as depository participants (DP).

Question 14
Converting physicalscripsinto computerized ledger accounts maintained by the depository is called
  • A.Dematerialization
  • B.Rematerialisation
  • C.Digitalization
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: Dematerialization

Converting physical scrips into computerized ledger accounts maintained by the depository is called Dematerialization. It is a process through which physical securities such as share certificates and other documents are converted into electronic format and held in a Demat Account.

 

Dematerialisation offers flexibility along with security and convenience. Holding share certificates in physical format carried risks like certificate forgeries, loss of important share certificates, and consequent delays in certificate transfers. Dematerialization eliminates these hassles by allowing customers to convert their physical certificates into electronic format.

 

A depository is responsible for holding the securities of a shareholder in electronic form. These securities could be in the form of bonds, government securities, and mutual fund units, which are held by a registered Depository Participant (DP). A DP is an agent of the depository providing depository services to traders and investors.

 

Currently, there are two depositories registered with SEBI and are licensed to operate in India:

 

(a) NSDL (National Securities Depository Ltd.)

(b) CDSL (Central Depository Services (India) Ltd.)

Question 15
A dividend declared by Board of Directors in between two Annual General Meetings of the Company is known as
  • A.final dividend
  • B.Interim dividend
  • C.quarterly dividend
  • D.Annual Dividend
Correct Answer: Interim dividend

Dividend is said to be an interim dividend, if it is declared by the Board of Directors between 2 AGMs of the company.

 

Dividend is said to be a final dividend if it is declared at the Annual General Meeting (AGM) of the company. Final dividend once declared becomes a debt enforceable against the company. Final Dividend can be declared only if it is recommended by the Board of Directors of the Company.

Question 16
Within how many days of declaration of dividend, the dividend should be paid to the members of the Company?
  • A.15 days
  • B.30 days
  • C.60 days
  • D.45 days
Correct Answer: 30 days

The dividend is paid to the members within 30 days from the date of its declaration.

Question 17
The unpaid dividend is transferred to Investor Education and Protection Fund after the expiry of how many years of transferring in unpaid dividend account?
  • A.2
  • B.5
  • C.7
  • D.10
Correct Answer: 7

Unpaid dividend is transferred to Investor Education and Protection Fund after the expiration of 7 years of transferring to unpaid dividend account.

Question 18
As per Companies Act, 2013, an association of persons carrying on any business for profits shall be termed as illegal association when the number of persons exceed?
  • A.10
  • B.50
  • C.100
  • D.20
Correct Answer: 100

An association of persons carrying on any business for profits shall be termed as illegal association when the number of persons exceed Hundred (100).

Question 19
What is the maximum number of audits that can be taken up bya person who is qualified as an auditor or a partner of a firm holding appointment as its auditor?
  • A.10
  • B.20
  • C.30
  • D.50
Correct Answer: 20

The maximum number of audits that can be taken up by a person who is qualified as an auditor or a partner of a firm holding appointment as its auditor is 20.

Question 20
First auditor of a company other than a government company is appointed by?
  • A.Board of directors
  • B.Shareholders
  • C.None of these
  • D.All of the above
Correct Answer: Board of directors

First auditor of a company other than a government company is appointed by Board of Directors within 30 days from the date of registration of the Company. If Board fails to make such appointment, the members shall appoint such Auditors in Extra-ordinary General Meeting within 90 days. Such auditor shall hold office till the conclusion of the first Annual General Meeting.

Question 21
As per the provisions of Companies Act, 2013, a private limited company must have how many directors?
  • A.2
  • B.3
  • C.4
  • D.5
Correct Answer: 2

The Act requires that every company must have at least:

3 directors in case of public limited companies,

2 directors in case of private limited companies and

1 director in case of one-person companies.

A company can have maximum 15 directors. The company could appoint more directors by passing the special resolution in its general meeting.

Question 22
As per the provisions of Companies Act, 2013, a public limited company must have how many directors?
  • A.2
  • B.3
  • C.4
  • D.5
Correct Answer: 3

The Act requires that every company must have at least:

  • 3 directors in case of public limited companies,
  • 2 directors in case of private limited companies and
  • 1 director in case of one-person companies.

A company can have maximum 15 directors. The company could appoint more directors by passing the special resolution in its general meeting.

Question 23
An individual can be appointed as a director (including alternate directorship) of not more than ____ companies at a time.
  • A.10
  • B.15
  • C.20
  • D.30
Correct Answer: 20

No person shall hold office as a director, including any alternate directorship, in more than 20 companies at the same time.

The maximum number of public companies in which a person can be appointed as a director shall not exceed 10.

Question 24
Match the following:List I (Type of Director)(a) Additional Director(b) Alternate Director(c) Independent DirectorList II (Feature)(i) other than WTD(ii)termconcludes up to the next AGM.(iii) Temporary DirectorCodes:
  • A.(a)-(i); (b)-(iii), (c)-(ii)
  • B.(a)-(i); (b)-(ii), (c)-(iii)
  • C.(a)-(iii); (b)-(ii), (c)-(i)
  • D.(a)-(ii); (b)-(iii), (c)-(i)
Correct Answer: (a)-(ii); (b)-(iii), (c)-(i)

(a) Additional Director - term concludes up to the next AGM

(b) Alternate Director – Temporary Director

(c) Independent Director – Other than WTD (whole time director)

 

Following are the different types of Directors under various sections of Companies Act, 2013:

Resident director (Sec. 149): A director who has lived in India for at least 182 days is a residential director. A company should have one residential director.

Executive directors: The executive director is a full-time (whole time) working director of the company. They have a higher responsibility towards the organization. The company and its employees expect them to be efficient and careful in all the dealings.

Non-Executive Directors: These are non- working directors and are not involved in the everyday working of the company. They might take part in the planning or policy-making process. They challenge the executive directors to come up with decisions and solutions that are in the best interest of the company.

Managing Directors (Sec. 196): They have a substantial ability to make decisions, manage and direct other members of the company. All Listed Companies and every public company having paid-up share capital of Rs. 10 Crore or more must appoint Managing Directors.

Small Shareholder Directors (Sec. 151): A listed company, could upon the notice of minimum 1000 small shareholders or 10% of the total number of the small shareholder, whichever is lower, shall have a director which would be elected by small shareholders.

Women directors (Sec. 149): The Listed companies or public company having a paid-up capital of Rs. 100 crores or turnover of Rs. 300 crore or more must have a women director.

Additional Directors (Sec. 161): A person could be appointed as an additional director and can occupy his post until next Annual General Meeting. In absence of the AGM, such term would conclude on the date on which such AGM should have been held.

Alternate director (Sec. 161): When a director is absent for more than 3 months; an alternate director comes on board on his behalf. He acts as a director for a temporary period. And can only hold office as permissible to the director whose office this director holds.

Nominee Director (Sec. 161): These Directors are appointed by specific class of shareholders, central government (in case of oppression and mismanagement), banks and financial institutions (in case of loan agreement) and other third parties (through contracts) represent the interest of the entity which appointed them.

Independent Director (Sec. 149): Independent directors are non-executive directors of a company and help the company to improve corporate credibility and enhance the governance standards. These are the Directors other than a managing director or a whole-time director or a nominee director.

Question 25
What is the maximum tenure (in terms of consecutive years) of an Independent Director with respect to his appointment in a Company?
  • A.2
  • B.3
  • C.5
  • D.6
Correct Answer: 5

The Independent directors shall hold office for 5 consecutive years; however, they shall be entitled to reappointment by passing a special resolution with the disclosure in the Board’s report. Further, no independent director shall hold office for more than 2 consecutive terms, but such independent director shall be eligible for appointment after the expiration of 3 years of ceasing to become an independent director, provided that an independent director shall not, during the said period of 3 years, be appointed in or be associated with the company in any other capacity, either directly or indirectly.

Question 26
With respect to place of holding the Board Meetings of a Company, select the statement which is true.
  • A.A Board Meeting must be held at Corporate office or Registered office of the Company
  • B.A Board Meeting may be held at any place in India only.
  • C.A Board Meeting may be held at any place, in India or aboard.
  • D.A Board Meeting must be held at the registered office of the Company.
Correct Answer: A Board Meeting may be held at any place, in India or aboard.

A Board Meeting may be held at any place, in India or aboard.

Board meetings can be held at any place whether it be a company’s registered office or head office or any other premises and whether or not it is within the same city, town, village or state in which the registered office of the company is situated. Board meeting can also be held at places other than these places including abroad.

Question 27
First Board Meeting of the Company should be held with _____ days from the date of its incorporation.
  • A.15
  • B.30
  • C.60
  • D.90
Correct Answer: 30

First Board meeting should be held within 30 days of the date of incorporation.

Question 28
As per the provisions of the Companies Act, 2013, what is the maximum time gap between two consecutive Board Meetings?
  • A.60 days
  • B.90 days
  • C.120 days
  • D.No maximum time gap prescribed
Correct Answer: 120 days

First Board meeting should be held within 30 days of the date of incorporation. Thereafter there shall be minimum of 4 Board meetings every year and not more than 120 days shall intervene between two consecutive Board meetings.

Question 29
In case of a One-person Company, what is the minimum time gap prescribed under the Companies Act, 2013 between two consecutive Board Meetings?
  • A.30 days
  • B.45 days
  • C.60 days
  • D.90 days
Correct Answer: 90 days

A One Person Company, small company and dormant company shall be deemed to have complied with the provisions of the Companies Act, if at least one meeting of the Board of Directors has been conducted in each half of a calendar year and the gap between the two meetings is not less than 90 days. However, this provision would not apply to a one-person company in which there is only one director on its Board.

Question 30
What is the minimum number of directors for the purpose of quorum of a board meeting of a company (other than one-person company & sec. 8 companies)?
  • A.2
  • B.3
  • C.5
  • D.No such provision
Correct Answer: 2

The quorum for a meeting of the Board of Directors of a company shall be 1/3rd of its total strength or 2 directors, whichever is higher, and the participation of the directors by video conferencing or by other audio-visual means shall also be counted for the purposes of quorum.

Question 31
What is the maximum permissible time-gap between two consecutive Annual General Meetings of a Company?
  • A.6 months
  • B.15 months
  • C.18 months
  • D.No such provision
Correct Answer: 15 months

Annual general meeting should be held once in each calendar year. First annual general meeting of the company should be held within 9 months from the closing of the first financial year. Hence it shall not be necessary for the company to hold any annual general meeting in the year of its incorporation. Subsequent annual general meeting of the company should be held within 6 months from the date of closing of the relevant financial year. The gap between two annual general meetings shall not exceed 15 months. One-person company is exempt from holding an AGM.

 

To sum up, last date for holding AGM other than the first AGM i.e. subsequent AGM:

1. AGM is to be held within 6 months of the close of relevant financial year.

2. Not more than 15 months shall elapse between the date of one AGM and that of the next. In other words, AGM is to be held within 15 months of last AGM.

3. AGM is to be held in each calendar year.

Question 32
Which of the following business are transacted as ordinary business at an Annual General Meeting of a Company?
  • A.the consideration of financial statements and the reports of the BOD and auditors
  • B.appointment of directors in place of those retiring;
  • C.the declaration of dividend
  • D.All of the above
Correct Answer: All of the above

All other businesses transacted at an AGM except the following are special business:

(i) the consideration of financial statements and the reports of the BOD and auditors;

(ii) the declaration of any dividend;

(iii) the appointment of directors in place of those retiring;

(iv) the appointment of, and the fixing of the remuneration of, the auditors.

Accordingly, above mentioned four businesses are ordinary business rest shall be deemed to be special business. Explanatory statement is not required for transacting any item of ordinary business. Further, in case of meeting other than AGM, all business shall be deemed to be special. Explanatory statement must be annexed to the notice for transacting every items of special business.

Question 33
Extra Ordinary General Meeting can be called by?
  • A.Board of DirectorsSuomotu
  • B.Board on the request of a requisition
  • C.Requisitionists
  • D.All of the above
Correct Answer: All of the above

The articles of association of the company make provisions for convening general meeting other than the annual general meeting, for matters relating to the business of the company, which cannot be deferred till next Annual General Meeting. All general meetings other than annual general meeting are called extra-ordinary general meetings (EGM). All the transactions dealt upon in an EGM shall be special business.

 

The Extra-ordinary General Meeting can be called by any of the following:

(1) By the Board Suo motu (on its own)

(2) By Board on requisition of members

(3) By requisitionists

(4) By Tribunal

Question 34
How much clear days’ notice is required to be served on members of the company before convening General Meeting of members of the Company?
  • A.21
  • B.30
  • C.15
  • D.45
Correct Answer: 21

A general meeting of a company may be called by giving not less than 21 clear days’ notice either in writing or through electronic mode. ‘Clear days’ means days exclusive of the day of the notice of service and of the day on which the meeting is held. In case of section 8 company, 14 days’ clear notice is required instead of 21 days.

Question 35
Petition for Compulsory winding up of a company can be filed by?
  • A.The company
  • B.Creditors and also by contributories
  • C.The Registrar
  • D.All of the above
Correct Answer: All of the above

Petition for Compulsory winding up of a Company can be filed by all of the above.

 

The procedures for Winding up of companies are provided under Chapter XX of the Companies Act, 2013 and Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code (IBC) of India 2016.

 

IBC consolidates and amends the laws relating to reorganisation and insolvency resolution of corporate persons, partnership firms and individuals in a time bound manner for maximisation of value of assets of such persons, to promote entrepreneurship, availability of credit and balance the interests of all the stakeholders including alteration in the order of priority of payment of Government dues and to establish an Insolvency and Bankruptcy Board of India, and for matters connected therewith or incidental thereto. The Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code, 2016 (IBC) was passed by the Parliament on 11 May 2016, received Presidential assent on 28 May 2016 and was notified in the official gazette on the same day.

 

Winding Up by the Tribunal: The provisions of Part I of Chapter XX of the Companies Act, 2013 shall apply to the winding up of a company by the Tribunal under this Act.

 

A company may be wound up by the Tribunal in following cases:

(a) If the company has, by special resolution, resolved that the company be wound up by the Tribunal;

(b) If the company has acted against the interests of the sovereignty and integrity of India or the security of the State;

(c) If on an application made by the Registrar or any other person authorized by the Central Government by notification under this Act, the Tribunal is of the opinion that the affairs of the company have been conducted in a fraudulent manner and that it is proper that the company be wound up;

(d) If the company has made a default in filing with the Registrar its financial statements or annual returns for immediately preceding 5 consecutive financial years; or

(e) If the Tribunal is of the opinion that it is just and equitable that the company should be wound up.

 

For commencing proceedings, a petition is to be made to the Tribunal by any of the following persons:

(a) the company;

(b) any contributory or contributories;

(c) all or any of the persons specified in clauses (a) and (b);

(d) the Registrar;

(e) any person authorised by the Central Government in that behalf; or

(f) In a case falling under clause (b) i.e. against sovereignty and integrity of India; by the Central Government or a State Government.

Question 36
The directors of a public company desire to authorize the managing director to invest from time to time surplus funds in the purchase of shares of other companies. State which statement is correct for the given case:
  • A.Such delegation of power is permissible without any condition
  • B.Such delegation of power is not valid
  • C.Such delegation is not permissible unless it is sanctioned by a resolution passed at the meeting of the Board with the consent of all the directors present at the meeting.
  • D.None of the above statement is correct
Correct Answer: Such delegation is not permissible unless it is sanctioned by a resolution passed at the meeting of the Board with the consent of all the directors present at the meeting.

Such delegation is not permissible unless it is sanctioned by a resolution passed at the meeting of the Board with the consent of all the directors present at the meeting.

Question 37
In the last audited Financial statement of Axe Ltd., an unlisted company, the aggregate of outstanding Loans, Borrowing, Debentures or deposits standsRs. 40crores. State which statement is correct based on the facts of the given case.
  • A.It is necessary for Axe Ltd. to constitute Audit Committee
  • B.It is not necessary for Axe Ltd. to constitute Audit Committee, as it is an unlisted company
  • C.It is not necessary for Axe Ltd. to constitute Audit Committee, as its outstanding loans or borrowing or debentures does not exceedRs. 50 Crore.
  • D.It is necessary for Axe Ltd. to constitute Audit Committee, as its outstanding loans or borrowing or debentures stands atRs. 40 Crore.
Correct Answer: It is not necessary for Axe Ltd. to constitute Audit Committee, as its outstanding loans or borrowing or debentures does not exceedRs. 50 Crore.

It is not necessary for Axe Ltd. to constitute Audit Committee, as its outstanding loans or borrowing or debentures does not exceed Rs. 50 Crore.

 

Applicability of Audit Committee: The Board of directors of every listed companies and the following classes of companies, as prescribed under Rule 6 of Companies (Meetings of Board and its powers) Rules, 2014 shall constitute an Audit Committee.

 

(i) all public companies with a paid-up capital of Rs.10 Crores or more;

(ii) all public companies having turnover of Rs.100 Crores or more;

(iii) all public companies, having in aggregate, outstanding loans or borrowings or debentures or deposits exceeding Rs. 50 Crores.

 

The paid-up share capital or turnover or outstanding loans, or borrowings or debentures or deposits, as the case may be, as existing on the date of last audited Financial Statements shall be taken into account for the purposes of this rule.

 

As per given case, it is not compulsory for Axe Ltd, (an unlisted company) to constitute an audit committee because the aggregate of outstanding Loans, borrowing, debentures or deposits is Rs. 40 crore.

Question 38
A company decided to keep the books of accounts at place other than registered office in India. Identify the correct statement.
  • A.The Company cannot do so.
  • B.The Company can do so only by passing Board Resolution.
  • C.The Company can do so by taking approval from Shareholders.
  • D.The Company can do so by passing Board Resolution along with intimation of full address of that other place in writing to ROC.
Correct Answer: The Company can do so by passing Board Resolution along with intimation of full address of that other place in writing to ROC.

As per the Companies Act 2013, books of accounts can be kept at any place in India.

Procedure: The BOD shall pass a resolution at Board Meeting within 7 days of the decision, it shall file with ROC a notice in writing giving the full address of another place.

Question 39
MCQ Private Ltd. having net worth of more thanRs. 500 but less thanRs. 1000 crore decided to form CSR Committee but the company has only 2 directors. Identify the correct statement based on the above facts.
  • A.MCQ Private Ltd. cannot do so as it has only 2 directors.
  • B.MCQ Private Ltd. can do so even with 2 directors which will be sufficient for constituting CSR Committee and also is required to form such committee as Net worth criterion is satisfied.
  • C.MCQ Private Ltd. is not under obligation to form CSR committee as it has net worth of more thanRs. 500 but less thanRs. 1000 crore
  • D.None of the above statement is correct.
Correct Answer: MCQ Private Ltd. can do so even with 2 directors which will be sufficient for constituting CSR Committee and also is required to form such committee as Net worth criterion is satisfied.

According to Section 135 of the Companies Act, 2013, every company having net worth of rupees 500 crore or more, or turnover of rupees 1000 crore or more or a net profit of rupees 5 crore or more during the immediately preceding financial year shall constitute a Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) Committee of the Board consisting of 3 or more directors, out of which at least 1 director shall be an independent director.

 

Where a company is not required to appoint an independent director under section 149(4), it shall have in its Corporate Social Responsibility Committee two or more directors.

 

As MCQ is not a listed company, the company is not required to appoint independent directors (as per Section 149(4)).

 

Hence, option B is correct that MCQ Private Ltd. can do so even with 2 directors which will be sufficient criterion for constituting CSR committee and also is required to form such committee as Net worth criterion is satisfied.

Question 40
Whether two or more persons can be appointed as a director of the company by a single resolution? Identify the true statement.
  • A.Can be appointed without any condition
  • B.Cannot be appointed
  • C.Can be appointed subject to certain conditions
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: Can be appointed subject to certain conditions

According to section 162(1) one director can be appointed by one resolution however there is an exception to this rule which states that sometimes two or more director can be appointed by single resolution, if resolution is earlier passed in shareholder’s meeting (i.e., General Meeting) that two or more directors will be appointed by a single resolution and no shareholder has voted against it.

Quiz Attempt #119480

Total Questions: 40
Question 1
A public limited company calledaurgent meeting giving a shorter notice before four days of such meeting to transact urgent business. In that meeting no independent Director was present.State which set of statements among the following is correct based on the facts of the above case?(i)shorterperiod means ‘giving less than seven (7) days’ notice in writing.(ii)anurgent meeting for a urgent purpose can be called by giving a shorter notice provided that at least one independent Director (if any) shall be present at the meeting.(iii)anurgent meeting for a urgent purpose can be called by giving a shorter notice provided that at least two independent Directors shall be present at the meeting.(iv) In absence of Independent Directors from such a meeting of the Board decisions taken at such meeting shall be circulated to all the directors.(v) It is not mandatory to state the fact in the notice that the meeting is being held at a shorter notice.Options:
  • A.(ii), (iv) and (v)
  • B.(i), (ii) and (v)
  • C.(i), (iii) and (iv)
  • D.(i), (ii) and (iv)
Correct Answer: (i), (ii) and (iv)

According to the Companies Act, 2013, an urgent meeting for a urgent purpose can be called by giving a shorter notice provided that at least one independent Director (if any) shall be present at the meeting. In absence of Independent Directors from such a meeting of the Board decisions taken at such meeting shall be circulated to all the directors and shall be final only on ratification, thereof by at least one Independent Director (if any). In the given case, as the independent Director is absent from the urgent meeting (on receiving the shorter notice); the provision of this section shall be deemed to have complied if the decisions taken at such meeting is circulated to all the Directors and it is ratified by at least one Independent Director.

 

Further, a meeting of the Board shall be called by giving not less than seven days’ notice in writing to every director at his address registered with the company, which means shorter period means ‘giving less than 7 days’ notice in writing.

Question 2
Under the provisions of the Companies Act, 2013, a person with respect to a company, is not eligible to become director?(i) if had been sentenced to imprisonment for not less than 6 months and a period of 5 years has not been elapsed from the date of expiry of the sentence(ii) if he has been convicted of any offence and sentenced to imprisonment for a period of 7 years or more(iii) he has been convicted of the offence dealing with related party transactions at any time during the last preceding 3 years(iv) if he has not paid any calls in respect of any shares of the company held by him, whether alone or jointly with others, and 3 months have elapsed from the last day fixed for the payment of the callOptions:
  • A.Statement (i) and (ii) are correct; Statement (iii) and (iv) are incorrect
  • B.Statement (i) (ii) and (iii) are correct, Statement (iv) is incorrect
