Question 8
Which of the following policy has lost its sheen consequent to implementation of the GST laws in India? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2020)
  • A.Monetary policy
  • B.Fiscal policy
  • C.Trade policy
  • D.Exim policy
Correct Answer: Fiscal policy

Fiscal policy is the means by which a government adjusts its spending levels and tax rates to monitor and influence a nation's economy. After implementation of GST, the tax rates are largely standardized.

Question 9
Which of the following are true of the Goods and Services Tax (GST) introduced in India in recent times? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2020)I. It is a destination-based taxII. It benefits producing states moreIII. It benefits consuming states moreIV. It is a progressive taxationV. It is an umbrella tax to improve ease of doing businessChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.II, IV, V only
  • B.I, III, IV only
  • C.I, IV, V only
  • D.I, III, V only
Correct Answer: I, III, V only

Statement I, III and V are true according to Goods and Services Tax (GST) introduced in India in recent times.

Statement II does not follow as GST benefits consuming states and not the producing states because of the input tax credit that the consumers get.

Statement IV is not true as it is a tax on consumption not income because of which it can be considered as regressive tax system as the poor have to pay more proportion for consuming the same goods then rich.

Question 10
Out of the following, which are not the features of GST 2017 in India? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2020)I. GST is applicable on supply of Goods and Services.II. GST is based on the principle of origin-based taxation rather than principle of destination-based consumption.III. Import of Goods is treated as Inter-state supplies and would be subject to IGST in addition to applicable Custom duties.IV. It is a dual taxation with Centre and State simultaneously levying it on a common base.V. GST is applicable to all Goods and Services without any exemptionsChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.I, II and V only
  • B.II, III and V only
  • C.II and V only
  • D.III, IV and V only
Correct Answer: II and V only

Statements II and V are not the features of GST Act 2017, all others are the features of the act. These are not the features of GST (Goods and Services Tax) from the options given in the question

I. GST is based on the principle of origin-based taxation rather than principle of destination-based consumption

II. GST is applicable to all Goods and Services without any exemptions

 

The salient features of GST are as under:

(i) GST would be applicable on “supply” of goods or services as against the present concept of tax on the manufacture of goods or on sale of goods or on provision of services.

(ii) GST would be based on the principle of destination-based consumption taxation as against the present principle of origin-based taxation.

(iii) It would be a dual GST with the Centre and the States simultaneously levying it on a common base. The GST to be levied by the Centre would be called Central GST (central tax- CGST) and that to be levied by the States [including Union territories with legislature] would be called State GST (state tax- SGST). Union territories without legislature would levy Union territory GST (union territory tax- UTGST).

(iv) Import of goods would be treated as inter-State supplies and would be subject to IGST in addition to the applicable customs duties.

(v) Import of services would be treated as inter-State supplies and would be subject to IGST.

(vi) GST would apply to all goods and services except Alcohol for human consumption.

(vii) GST on five specified petroleum products (Crude, Petrol, Diesel, and ATF& Natural gas) would be applicable from a date to be recommended by the GSTC.

(viii) The list of exempted goods and services would be kept to a minimum and it would be harmonized for the Centre and the States as well as across States as far as possible.

Question 11
Which of the following commodities is kept outside the purview of GST? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2019)
  • A.Tobacco products
  • B.Petroleum products
  • C.Edible oils
  • D.Insurance products
Correct Answer: Petroleum products

Following are the goods which are kept outside the realm of GST:

(1) Alcohol for human consumption - It is outside the realm of GST. The manufacture/production of alcoholic liquor continues to be subjected to State excise duty and inter-State/intra-State sale of the same is subject to VAT/CST respectively.

(2) Petroleum Products viz. petroleum crude, motor spirit (petrol), high speed diesel, natural gas and aviation turbine fuel - These are not presently leviable to GST. GST will be levied on these products from a date to be notified on the recommendations of the GST Council. Till such date, central excise duty continues to be levied on manufacture/production of petroleum crude, diesel, petrol, ATF and natural gas and inter-State/intra-State sale of the same is subject to VAT/CST respectively.

(3) Real estate sector has been kept out of ambit of GST, i.e., GST will not be levied on sale/purchase of immovable property.

Point to be kept in mind:

Tobacco is within the purview of GST, i.e., GST is leviable on tobacco. However, Union Government has also retained the power to levy excise duties on tobacco and tobacco products manufactured in India. Resultantly, tobacco is subject to GST as well as central excise duty.

Question 12
Taxable event under GST means?
  • A.Supply of goods or services or both
  • B.Production of Goods or provision of services or both
  • C.Transaction involving supply of goods or services with or without consideration
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: Supply of goods or services or both

Taxable event under GST means supply of goods or services or both.

Taxable event under GST law is supply of goods or services or both. It means no supply no GST. Supply should have the following features under GST:

1. Supply of anything other than goods or services does not attract GST.

2. Supply should be made for a consideration.

3. Supply should be made in the course or furtherance of business.

4. Supply should be made by a taxable person.

5. Supply should be a taxable supply.

6. Supply should be made within the taxable territory.

 

Exceptions:

(1) Any transaction involving supply of goods or services without consideration is not a supply, barring few exceptions, in which a transaction is deemed to be a supply even without consideration.

(2) Further, import of services for a consideration, whether or not in the course or furtherance of business is treated as supply.

Question 13
Under GST, time of supply is an important consideration for payment of tax. Time of supply of goods is:(i) Date of issue of invoice(ii) Date of provision of services (if invoice is not issued within prescribed period)(iii) Date of receipt of advance/ payment.(iv) Date of production of goodsOptions :
  • A.Earliest of (i), (ii) or (iv) above
  • B.Earliest of (i), (ii) or (iii) above
  • C.Earliest of (i) or (ii) above
  • D.Earliest of (ii), (iii) or (iv) above
Correct Answer: Earliest of (i), (ii) or (iii) above

Time of supply means the point in time when goods/services are considered supplied’. When the seller knows the ‘time’, it helps him identify due date for payment of taxes.

Time of supply of goods is earliest of:

1. Date of issue of invoice

2. Last date on which invoice should have been issued

3. Date of receipt of advance/ payment*

*Note: GST is not applicable to advances under GST. GST in Advance is payable at the time of issue of the invoice. Notification No. 66/2017 – Central Tax issued on 15.11.2017

 

Time of supply of services is earliest of:

1. Date of issue of invoice

2. Date of receipt of advance/ payment.

3. Date of provision of services (if invoice is not issued within prescribed period)

Question 14
What are Capital Goods under GST?
  • A.which are exclusively meant for import
  • B.which mayusedfor consumption as well as furtherance of business
  • C.which are intended to be used for consumption
  • D.which are intended to be used in the course of furtherance of business
Correct Answer: which are intended to be used in the course of furtherance of business

As per Central Goods and Service Tax, 2017, ‘capital goods’ means the goods, the value of which is capitalized in the books of account of the person claiming the input tax credit and which are used or intended to be used in the course or furtherance of business.

Question 15
Match the following with respect to “Audit” under GST.List I(a) Audit of Taxable person(b) General Audit(c) Special AuditList II(i) Audit in the interest of revenue(ii) Audit on commissioner’s order(iii) Turnover during a FY exceeds specified limitOptions:
  • A.(a)-(i),(b)-(ii),(c)-(iii)
  • B.(a)-(iii),(b)-(ii),(c)-(i)
  • C.(a)-(ii),(b)-(iii),(c)-(i)
  • D.(a)-(ii),(b)-(i),(c)-(iii)
Correct Answer: (a)-(iii),(b)-(ii),(c)-(i)

(a) Audit of Taxable Person - Turnover during a FY exceeds specified limit

(b) General Audit - Audit on commissioner’s order

(c) Special Audit - Audit in the interest of revenue

 

Audit under GST is the examination of records maintained by a registered dealer. The aim is to verify the correctness of information declared, taxes paid and to assess the compliance with GST.

 

a. Audit of Registered Dealer/ Taxable Person

Every registered dealer whose turnover during a financial year exceeds the Rs 2 crore has to get his accounts audited by a CA (Chartered Accountant) or a CMA (Certified Management Accountant). ICAI clarifies through an announcement dated 28th September 2018 that an Internal Auditor cannot undertake GST Audit simultaneously.

 

b. Audit by GST Tax Authorities

General Audit: The commissioner or on his orders an officer may conduct an audit of any registered dealer.

Special Audit: The department may conduct a special audit due to the complexity of the case and considering the interest of revenue. The CA or a CMA will be appointed to conduct the audit.

Question 16
Match the following with respect to GST provisions.List 1(a) Demand and Recovery(b) Advance Ruling(c) Assessments(d) AuditsList 2(i)determination of tax liability(ii) incorrect payment of tax(iii) examination or records maintained by a registered dealer(iv) avoidance of LitigationOptions:
  • A.(a)-(i) (b)-(ii) (c)-(iii) (d)-(iv)
  • B.(a)-(iii) (b)-(i) (c)-(iv) (d)-(ii)
  • C.(a)-(iv) (b)-(ii) (c)-(i) (d)-(iii)
  • D.(a)-(ii) (b)-(iv) (c)-(i) (d)-(iii)
Correct Answer: (a)-(ii) (b)-(iv) (c)-(i) (d)-(iii)

(a) Demand and Recovery - incorrect payment of tax

(b) Advance Ruling - avoidance of Litigation

(c) Assessments - determination of tax liability

(d) Audits - examination or records maintained by a registered dealer

 

Broadly, the GST Procedures can be listed as:

1. Audits

2. Assessment

3. Demand and Recovery

4. Advance Ruling

 

These are explained below:

 

1. AUDITS

Audit under GST is the examination of records maintained by a registered dealer. The aim is to verify the correctness of information declared, taxes paid and to assess the compliance with GST.

a. Audit of Registered Dealer/ Taxable Person

Every registered dealer whose turnover during a financial year exceeds the Rs 2 crore has to get his accounts audited by a CA (Chartered Accountant) or a CMA (Certified Management Accountant).ICAI clarifies through an announcement dated 28th September 2018 that an Internal Auditor cannot undertake GST Audit simultaneously.

b. Audit by GST Tax Authorities

General Audit: The commissioner or on his orders an officer may conduct an audit of any registered dealer.

Special Audit: The department may conduct a special audit due to the complexity of the case and considering the interest of revenue. The CA or a CMA will be appointed to conduct the audit.

 

2. ASSESSMENTS

Assessment under GST means the determination of tax liability under GST and has been divided into 5 types:

a. Self-Assessment - Under GST, every registered taxable person shall assess the taxes payable by them on their own, and furnish a return for each tax period. This is called self-assessment.

b. Provisional Assessment - A registered dealer can request the officer for provisional assessment if he is unable to determine the value of goods or rate of tax. The proper officer can allow the assessee to pay tax on a provisional basis at a rate or a value specified by him.

c. Scrutiny Assessment - A GST officer can scrutinize the return to verify its correctness. The officer will ask for explanations on any discrepancies noticed in the returns.

d. Summary Assessment - Summary Assessment is done when the assessing officer comes across sufficient grounds to believe any delay in showing a tax liability which can harm the interest of the revenue. To protect the interest of the revenue, he can pass the summary assessment with the prior permission of the additional/joint commissioner.

e. Best Judgement Assessment- (1) Assessment of non-filers of returns - If a registered taxable person does not file his return even after getting a notice, the proper officer will assess the tax liability to the best of his judgment using the available relevant material. (2) Assessment of unregistered persons - This assessment is done when a taxable person fails to obtain registration even though he is liable to do so.

The officer will assess the tax liability of such persons to the best of his judgement. The taxable person will receive a show cause notice and an opportunity of being heard.

 

3. DEMAND AND RECOVERY

Demand and recovery provisions are applicable when a registered dealer has paid tax incorrectly or not paid tax at all. It is also applicable when an incorrect refund or ITC is claimed by the dealer.

The proper officer will issue a show cause notice along with a demand for payment of tax and penalty in case of fraud.

Demands can arise in the following cases:

1. Unpaid or short paid tax or wrong refund

2. Tax collected but not deposited with the Central or a State Government

3. CGST/SGST paid when IGST was payable and vice versa.

 

If demand is not paid, the GST authority starts recovery proceedings.

 

4. ADVANCE RULING

Advance Ruling under GST means seeking clarifications from GST authority on certain tax matters before starting the proposed activity. This helps to reduce costly litigation.

An advance ruling is a written decision given by the tax authority to an applicant on queries related to the supply of goods/services.

Question 17
Whendid Central Goods and Service Tax Actreceived assent from President?
  • A.September 2016
  • B.September 2017
  • C.October 2016
  • D.October 2017
Correct Answer: September 2016

Goods and Services Tax (GST) is an indirect tax. GST was first mooted in the year 2003 by Kelkar Task Force on indirect taxes, who had suggested subsuming various central and state indirect taxes into one indirect tax. To implement this vision, an Empowered Committee known as Kelkar committee of State Finance Ministers was created and tasked with the responsibility of ironing out the differences and taking this monumental reform forward.

The GST Bill was discussed in length in Parliament in order to end the prevailing taxation system of imposing various indirect taxes and implement a new system in which most of these taxes will be covered under one umbrella.

On 8th September, 2016, President Pranab Mukherjee gave assent to this Bill, making it an Act called the Central Goods and Services Tax Act, 2017.

Question 18
GST council has its Secretarial office at?
  • A.Kolkata
  • B.New Delhi
  • C.Mumbai
  • D.Chennai
Correct Answer: New Delhi

The GST council, the key decision-making body that will take all important decisions regarding the GST, will have representation from the central governments as well as all the state governments.

 

The Goods & Services Tax Council (GST Council) has been created in September 2016 under Article279-A of the Constitution of India. It has its Secretariat office in New Delhi

Question 19
Sin Products refers to?
  • A.products injurious to health
  • B.only junk food products
  • C.Products which are distributed as Sample Products
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: products injurious to health

The concept of ‘Sin Products’ refers to those products which are injurious to health like tobacco, cigarettes.

Question 20
GSTIN refers to?
  • A.PAN-based 12-digit Goods and Services Taxpayer Identification Number
  • B.TAN-based 12-digit Goods and Services Taxpayer Identification Number
  • C.TAN-based 15-digit Goods and Services Taxpayer Identification Number
  • D.PAN-based 15-digit Goods and Services Taxpayer Identification Number
Correct Answer: PAN-based 15-digit Goods and Services Taxpayer Identification Number

GSTIN refers to the unique GST identification number that every business will be allotted. Every taxpayer will be allotted a state-wise, PAN-based 15-digit Goods and Services Taxpayer Identification Number (GSTIN). Also, note that having PAN is mandatory for register under GST.

Question 21
Which of the following statements are correct with respect to Place of Supply of Goods with reference to GST?
  • A.Place of supply in cases where goods that are assembled and installed will be the location where the installation is done.
  • B.theplace of supply of goods is the place where the ownership of goods changes.
  • C.Where there is no movement of goods, the place of supply is the location of goods at the time of delivery to the recipient.
  • D.All of the above
Correct Answer: All of the above

Place of Supply of Goods

Usually, in case of goods, the place of supply is where the goods are delivered.

So, the place of supply of goods is the place where the ownership of goods changes.

Where there is no movement of goods, the place of supply is the location of goods at the time of delivery to the recipient.

Place of supply in cases where goods that are assembled and installed will be the location where the installation is done.

 

Place of Supply for Services

Generally, the place of supply of services is the location of the service recipient.

In cases where the services are provided to an unregistered dealer and their location is not available, the location of service provider will be the place of provision of service.

Special provisions have been made to determine the place of supply for the following services:

- Services related to immovable property

- Restaurant services

- Admission to events

- Transportation of goods and passengers

- Telecom services

- Banking, Financial and Insurance services.

Question 22
GST is a ______ based tax on consumption of goods and services.
  • A.Duration
  • B.Destination
  • C.Both A and B
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: Destination

GST is a destination-based tax on consumption of goods and services. The main objective of GST is to eliminate excessive taxation.

Question 23
What does “I” stand for in IGST?
  • A.International
  • B.Internal
  • C.Integrated
  • D.Indian
Correct Answer: Integrated

“IGST” stands for Integrated Goods and Service Tax.

 

IGST is a mechanism to monitor the inter-state trade of goods and services and ensure that the SGST component accrues to the Consumer State. It would maintain the integrity of ITC (Input Tax Credit) chain in inter-state supplies. The IGST rate would broadly be equal to CGST rate plus SGST rate. IGST would be levied and collected by the Central Government on all inter-State transactions of taxable goods or services. The revenue of inter-state sales will not accrue to the exporting state and the exporting state will be required to transfer to the Centre the credit of SGST/UTGST used in payment of IGST.

Question 24
How many types of taxes are there in Indian GST?
  • A.2
  • B.3
  • C.4
  • D.5
Correct Answer: 3

State GST (SGST)/Union Territory GST (UTGST), Central GST (CGST) and IGST are three types of taxes.

 

India adopted a dual GST where tax imposed concurrently by the Central and States.

Question 25
Which of the following tax is not subsumed in GST?
  • A.VAT
  • B.Stamp Duty
  • C.Entertainment Tax
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: Stamp Duty

Stamp Duty is not subsumed in GST.

 

At the central level, following taxes are being subsumed under GST

(i) Central Excise Duty

(ii) Additional Excise Duty

(iii) Service Tax

(iv) Countervailing Duty

(v) Special Additional Duty of Customs

 

At the state level, following taxes are being subsumed under GST

(i) State VAT/Sales Tax

(ii) Entertainment Tax

(iii) Central Sales Tax

(iv) Octroi and Entry Tax

(v) Purchase Tax

(vi) Luxury Tax

(vii) Taxes on lottery, betting and gambling

Question 26
What are the taxes levied on intra-state supply?
  • A.CGST
  • B.SGST
  • C.CGST and SGST
  • D.IGST
Correct Answer: CGST and SGST

CGST and SGST is levied on intra-state supply.

Question 27
What is the maximum rate prescribed under CGST?
  • A.12%
  • B.20%
  • C.28%
  • D.18%
Correct Answer: 20%

As per the provisions of CGST, there shall be levied a tax called the central goods and services tax on all intra-State supplies of goods or services or both, except on the supply of alcoholic liquor for human consumption, on the value determined under section 15 and at such rates, not exceeding twenty per cent, as may be notified by the Government on the recommendations of the Council and collected in such manner as may be prescribed and shall be paid by the taxable person.

Question 28
How will the goods and services be classified under GST regime?
  • A.SAC/ HSN code
  • B.HSN code
  • C.SAC code
  • D.GST code
Correct Answer: SAC/ HSN code

For Goods – HSN Code and for Services – SAC Code

 

HSN Code: The Harmonized Commodity Description and Coding System generally refers to “Harmonized System of Nomenclature” or simply “HSN”. It is a multipurpose international product nomenclature developed by the World Customs Organization (WCO). It first came into effect in 1988. It has about 5,000 commodity groups, each identified by a six-digit code, arranged in a legal and logical structure. It is supported by well-defined rules to achieve uniform classification. The main purpose of HSN is to classify goods from all over the World in a systematic and logical manner. This brings in a uniform classification of goods and facilitates international trade.

 

SAC Code: Like goods, services are also classified uniformly for recognition, measurement and taxation. Codes for services are called Services Accounting Code or SAC.

Question 29
Which of the following is an intrastate supply?
  • A.Supplier of goods located in Nagpur and place of supply of goods SEZ located in Mumbai
  • B.Supplier of goods located in Kolkata and place of supply of goods in Bangalore
  • C.Supplier of goods located in Goa and place of supply of goods in Goa
  • D.All of the above
Correct Answer: Supplier of goods located in Goa and place of supply of goods in Goa

Intra-state Supply: Under GST, supply of goods or services within the same state or Union territory is called as intrastate supply. However, supply of goods or services to a Special Economic Zone developer or Special Economic Zone unit situated within the same state would not be intrastate supply. As any supply of goods or services to a Special Economic Zone developer or Special Economic Zone unit is classified as interstate supply.

 

Inter-state Supply: Under GST, supply of goods or services from one state to another would be called as interstate supply. The GST Act defines interstate supply as when the location of the supplier and the place of supply for the customer are in:

 

(a) Two different States; or

(b) Two different Union territories; or

(c) State and a Union territory.

 

In addition to the above, the supply of goods imported into India, till they cross the customs station is also classified as interstate supply. Also, supply of goods or services to or by a Special Economic Zone developer or a Special Economic Zone unit is classified as interstate supply.

Question 30
Place of supply in case of installation of elevator is
  • A.Where the movement of elevator commences from the supplier’s place
  • B.Where the delivery of elevator is taken
  • C.Where the installation of elevator is made
  • D.Where address of the recipient is mentioned in the invoice.
Correct Answer: Where the installation of elevator is made

Place of supply in case of installation of elevator is where the installation of elevator is made.

 

Place of Supply of Goods

Usually, in case of goods, the place of supply is where the goods are delivered. So, the place of supply of goods is the place where the ownership of goods changes.

 

Where there is no movement of goods, the place of supply is the location of goods at the time of delivery to the recipient. Place of supply in cases where goods that are assembled and installed will be the location where the installation is done.

 

Place of Supply for Services

Generally, the place of supply of services is the location of the service recipient.

In cases where the services are provided to an unregistered dealer and their location is not available, the location of service provider will be the place of provision of service.

Special provisions have been made to determine the place of supply for the following services:

• Services related to immovable property

• Restaurant services

• Admission to events

• Transportation of goods and passengers

• Telecom services

• Banking, Financial and Insurance services.

Question 31
Which one of the following is true with respect to GST?
  • A.A person can collect tax only he is registered.
  • B.Registered person not liable to collect tax till his aggregate turnover exceeds threshold limit
  • C.A person can collect the tax during the period of his provisional registration
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: A person can collect tax only he is registered.

Only a registered taxable person can collect GST. The taxable person must prominently indicate the GST amount on tax invoices.

Question 32
Which of the following has not been subsumed under GST?
  • A.State VAT
  • B.Entertainment Tax (except those levied by local authorities)
  • C.Property Tax
  • D.Central Sales Tax
Correct Answer: Property Tax

Property tax is not subsumed under GST.

At the central level, following taxes are being subsumed under GST

(i) Central Excise Duty

(ii) Additional Excise Duty

(iii) Service Tax

(iv) Countervailing Duty

(v) Special Additional Duty of Customs

 

At the state level, following taxes are being subsumed under GST

(i) State VAT/Sales Tax

(ii) Entertainment Tax

(iii) Central Sales Tax

(iv) Octroi and Entry Tax

(v) Purchase Tax

(vi) Luxury Tax

(vii) Taxes on lottery, betting and gambling

Question 33
Which of the following is not one of members/chairperson of GST Council?
  • A.Union Finance Minister
  • B.Union Minister of State in charge of Revenue or Finance
  • C.Minister in charge of Finance of State
  • D.Chairman of CBIC
Correct Answer: Chairman of CBIC

The GST council is the key decision-making body that will take all important decisions regarding the GST. The council will have representation from the central governments as well as all the state governments. The Goods & Services Tax Council (GST Council) has been created in September 2016 under Article 279-A of the Constitution of India. It has its Secretariat office in New Delhi.

 

The Council shall consist of the following members, namely:

(a) the Union Finance Minister - Chairperson;

(b) the Union Minister of State in charge of Revenue or Finance - Member;

(c) the Minister in charge of Finance or Taxation or any other Minister nominated by each State Government - Members.

One-half of the total number of Members of the Goods and Services Tax Council shall constitute the quorum at its meetings.

Question 34
Usually, when the supplier supplies goods, the tax is levied upon the supplier. In certain cases, the tax is levied upon the buyer of the goods. This is called _______.
  • A.Input Tax Credit
  • B.Reverse charge
  • C.Counter charge
  • D.Cross charge
Correct Answer: Reverse charge

Reverse charge means the liability to pay tax is on the recipient of supply of goods or services instead of the supplier of such goods or services in respect of notified categories of supply. Under reverse charge mechanism, the statutory liability to deposit GST and undertaking compliance requirements, i.e., to obtain registration under GST, deposit tax with the Government, filing returns, etc., shifts from supplier to recipient. It is to be noted that ‘forward charge’ means where supplier is liable to pay tax.

Question 35
Every registered dealer whose turnover during a financial year exceeds ________ has to get his accounts audited by a CA or a CMA.
  • A.Rs. 40 Lakhs
  • B.Rs. 50 Lakhs
  • C.Rs. 2 Crore
  • D.Rs. 3 Crore
Correct Answer: Rs. 2 Crore

Audit under GST is the examination of records maintained by a registered dealer. The aim is to verify the correctness of information declared, taxes paid and to assess the compliance with GST.

 

a. Audit of Registered Dealer/ Taxable Person

Every registered dealer whose turnover during a financial year exceeds the Rs 2 crore has to get his accounts audited by a CA (Chartered Accountant) or a CMA (Certified Management Accountant). ICAI clarifies through an announcement dated 28th September 2018 that an Internal Auditor cannot undertake GST Audit simultaneously.

 

b. Audit by GST Tax Authorities

General Audit: The commissioner or on his orders an officer may conduct an audit of any registered dealer.

Special Audit: The department may conduct a special audit due to the complexity of the case and considering the interest of revenue. The CA or a CMA will be appointed to conduct the audit.

Question 36
This type of assessment is done when the assessing officer comes across sufficient grounds to believe any delay in showing a tax liability can harm the interest of the revenue. Identify the type of assessment.
  • A.Scrutiny Assessment
  • B.Summary Assessment
  • C.Best Judgement Assessment
  • D.Provisional Assessment
Correct Answer: Summary Assessment

Summary Assessment is done when the assessing officer comes across sufficient grounds to believe any delay in showing a tax liability which can harm the interest of the revenue. To protect the interest of the revenue, he can pass the summary assessment with the prior permission of the additional/joint commissioner.

Question 37
Seeking clarifications from GST authority on certain tax matters would mean _________.
  • A.Best judgement
  • B.Summary Assessment
  • C.Demand Order
  • D.Advance Ruling
Correct Answer: Advance Ruling

Advance Ruling under GST means seeking clarifications from GST authority on certain tax matters before starting the proposed activity. This helps to reduce costly litigation.

An advance ruling is a written decision given by the tax authority to an applicant on queries related to the supply of goods/services.

Question 38
The GST would apply to all goods, EXCEPT:
  • A.Alcoholic liquor for human consumption
  • B.Luxury cars
  • C.Precious Metals
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: Alcoholic liquor for human consumption

The GST would apply to all goods other than alcoholic liquor for human consumption and 5 petroleum products, viz. petroleum crude, motor spirit (petrol), high speed diesel, natural gas and aviation turbine fuel.

Question 39
Provisional Input Tax Credit can be utilised against: (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2022)
  • A.Any tax liability
  • B.Self-assessed tax liability
  • C.Differential income tax gains
  • D.Fine
Correct Answer: Self-assessed tax liability

Provisional Input Tax Credit can be utilized against self-assessed tax liability.

 

Provisional Input Tax Credit (ITC) is the credit that is made available to taxpayers for the tax paid on their purchases of goods and services, which can be utilized to set off their tax liability. It is called "provisional" because it is based on the taxpayer's own assessment of their tax liability, which may be subject to adjustment by the tax authorities at a later stage.

 

As per the GST (Goods and Services Tax) law in India, provisional ITC can be utilized by a taxpayer against their self-assessed tax liability, which means the tax liability that is declared by the taxpayer in their monthly/quarterly GST returns.

 

However, the provisional ITC cannot be utilized against any other type of tax liability, such as income tax gains or fines. It can only be utilized to set off the tax liability under the GST law.

Question 40
Which of the following are the tax categories under the GST? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2022)a. 5%b. 10%c. 12%d. 20%e. 28%Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.a, d, e only
  • B.b, c, d only
  • C.a, c, e only
  • D.b, d, e only
Correct Answer: a, c, e only

Owing to unique Indian socio-economic milieu, four rates namely 5%, 12%, 18% and 28% have been adopted under GST. Besides, some goods and services are exempt also. Rate for precious metals and affordable housing are an exception to ‘four-tax slab-rule’ and the same has been fixed at 3% and 1% respectively. In addition, unworked diamonds, precious stones, etc. attracts a rate of 0.25%. A cess over the peak rate of 28% on certain specified luxury and demerit goods, like tobacco and tobacco products, pan masala, aerated water, motor vehicles is imposed to compensate States for any revenue loss on account of implementation of GST.

Export of goods and services are zero rated. Supplies to SEZs developers and SEZ units are also zero-rated.

The GST would apply to all goods other than alcoholic liquor for human consumption and 5 petroleum products, viz. petroleum crude, motor spirit (petrol), high speed diesel, natural gas and aviation turbine fuel.

Quiz Attempts 521-530 of 849
